item.description:
Experiment2_E2_PhenotypingLCNV FA, FP

Isolate CD8 from NaIodide mouse, adoptive transfer into laser burn mouse
CD8TcellBeadIsolation
one spleen, from sodium iodide mouse.
Splenocytes ~ 2e7
CSFE staining
Add MCSF to bone marrow cell cultures
E1_TimeCourseLaserLCNV 2nd laser burn event

7 days after bone marrow culture, 6 days with MCSF.
Add IL-33 at varying concentrations?
for varying times?
need to determine this!

Did Macrophage Panel on 6 eyes from DKO (ST2 KO and VLDR KO) and 6 eyes from VKO mice.
Tissue digestion:
0.5mg/ml Elastase
1 mg/ml Hyaluronidase
2mg/ml Collagenase IV
120 u/ml DNAse I
30 at 37c minutes with ~3 episodes of trituration.
Extended 15 minutes at 37c

item.title: CD8 Tmem thoughts_connections
item.description:
TmemDefsAndConcepts referring to CD8 central memory - CCR7 positive - lymphoid homing receptor
another ref defining ccr7 in central and effector mem
Il7r super high in cluster 10 "migratory". "migratory" definition based on ccr7 but ccr7 is on central and effector memory. Homeostatic proliferation also also
this reftalks about other non CTL functions of cd8 including b-cell help on the basis of il21 secretion, also SLAMF7, IL6r expression distinguishing between cytotoxic and helper
il6r = helper
slamf7 cytotoxic
ITGAL - highest 4/15 but also some expression in 10
this is cd11a and it is involved in trafficking to inflamed tissues
L-selectin high in 10. super super high. completely absent in 4 and 15 expressed by both naive and central memory cd8t
ITGA4 aka CD49d is highly expressed on antigen experienced cells
In our dataset, all 3 cd8 populations have high ITGA4
this single cell study defined cytotoxic CD8 on NKG7 high, GZMk and b high, prf1 high

item.title: Endogenous Inhibitors of Angiogenesis
item.description: IL18 here and here

item.title: TmemDefsAndConcepts
item.description:
Concepts of Tmem derived form this review
PMID: 34127444 2022

Defining memory has been done previously with a broad brush
Defining Tmem has greater complexity
More so in the CD8 Tmem pool?
Epigenetic state to define CD8 Tmem?
Classic definitions:

Faster response to Antigen
Naive produce IL-2/IFN-y within 12 hours while Tmem < 3hours
CD8 Tmem kill in vitro in under 5 hours
- in vivo LCMV model - 49-89% target kills are dead <4 hours, eradication in <24hours
- compared to naive which have zero capacity to kill.
Defining traits:
CD8 Tmem produce a large amount of IL-2 and IFN-y
CD8 Tmem persist without antigen
LCMV-sp CD8 can be adoptively txferred and persist "indefinitely": nature ref 1994
CD8 Tmem can survive in absence of TCR in mhc-I or b2 macroglobulin knockouts here and here
Mechanism? stochastic mitosis ~50 day intervals here
overall take-home message
CD8 Tmem have rapid recall and persist independent of Ag


Isoforms of CD45 form broad discrimination between naive and memory T cells
Circulating properties of Tmem are classified by CCR7 NOTE: These are human definitions
CCR7+ CD45RA- Central Memory - Greater prolif. capacity
CCR7- CD45RA- Effector Memory - Greater cytokine producing, more markers of tissue homing
Mouse Analogues:
CD44+ CD62L+ Central memory nature immuno
CD44+ CD62L- Effector memory
Resident memory: CD69+ CD103+ found by parabiosis
Stem-like CD8 Tmem
CD45RA+CCR7+ also CD122+ CD95+here
Defining memory is strictly done on the basis of antigen recognition.
Using surface markers is an inference based on the fact that memory cells also upregulated those markers in the literature.
E.g. OT-1 CD8 AT into irradiated hosts upregulate CD44 yet have never seen antigen which is due to homeostatic proliferation. in other words, naive t cells look like memory. also shown here
Naive cells in this scenario do not have the same cytokine or proliferation properties as memory demonstrated again by the goldrath group and cheng group
CD45 expression is confusing at best. Early studies led people to understand that CD45RA expression is naive, but that is misleading. By tetramer staining, Ag-sp CD8 T cells at peak of vaccine response are CD45RA-CCR7-, but re-expressed CD45 in a month here also hereand here
Thus, truly defining CD8 Tmem by markers is frought. Epigenetic definitions may give clarity to this problem.
Recent studies doing this: russ 2014 gray youngblood
epigentic programs are durable changes observed to be persistent in humans for years also here
lacking epigenetic data - this may offer some insight to defining memory by transcriptomics, however I have not reviewed this carefully

aka memory phenotype.
naive inexperienced. approx 5-15% of circulating cd8
express conventional memory markers CD44, CD122 (high on both)
low levels of cd49d
relevant bc cd49d is upregulated on antigen experience - "permanently"
Tvmem are likely trained in the thymus on self peptide
also have elevated cd5 and eomes
highly sensitive to il15
high eomes drives high il2rb

ref

item.title: Calculate the total number of elements in the matrix
item.description:
#Alternatively
#####Calculate Sparsity#####
counts_matrix <- GetAssayData(iodide.data, slot = "counts")

total_elements <- length(counts_matrix)

zero_elements <- sum(counts_matrix == 0)

sparsity <- zero_elements / total_elements

cat("Sparsity of the dataset:", sparsity, "\n")

cat("Percentage sparsity of the dataset:", sparsity * 100, "%", "\n")
######Calculate Seq Depth#####

sequencing_depth <- iodide.data$nCount_RNA

summary(sequencing_depth)

hist(sequencing_depth, breaks = 50, main = "Sequencing Depth per Cell",
xlab = "UMI Counts", ylab = "Number of Cells", col = "skyblue")
#Alternatively, you can add a violin plot for visualizing sequencing depth distribution
VlnPlot(iodide.data, features = "nCount_RNA", pt.size = 0.1) +
ggtitle("Sequencing Depth Distribution")

median_depth <- median(sequencing_depth)
cat("Median sequencing depth:", median_depth, "\n")
#####Calculate UMI counts per gene#####


umi_counts_per_cell <- iodide.data$nCount_RNA

average_umi_per_cell <- mean(umi_counts_per_cell)

cat("Average sequencing depth per cell (UMI counts):", average_umi_per_cell, "\n")




num_genes_per_cell <- iodide.data$nFeature_RNA

average_genes_per_cell <- mean(num_genes_per_cell)

estimated_depth <- average_umi_per_cell / average_genes_per_cell
cat("Estimated sequencing depth (UMI counts per gene):", estimated_depth, "\n")
#####Search Seurat Features for an input gene#####
features <- Features(iodide.data.sc)

matches <- grep("Tnfrsf", features)

print(matches)
matching_elements <- features[matches]
print(matching_elements)

marker_list <- c("Marker1", "Marker2", "Marker3")

seurat_objRNA@data[marker_list, ])

FeaturePlot(seurat_obj, features = "combined_feature")


seurat_objcombined_feature > 0

FeaturePlot(seurat_obj, features = "marker_positive")

CD8_cells <- subset(seurat_obj, subset = CD8A > 0 | CD8B > 0)

CD8_subset <- FindClusters(CD8_subset)

FeaturePlot(CD8_subset, features = c("CD8A", "CD8B"))


CD8_subset <- subset(seurat_obj, subset = CD8A > 0 | CD8B > 0)

CD8_subset <- FindNeighbors(CD8_subset, dims = 1:10)
CD8_subset <- FindClusters(CD8_subset, resolution = 0.5)

DimPlot(CD8_subset, label = TRUE)


features_to_use <- c("CD8A", "CD8B", VariableFeatures(seurat_obj))

seurat_obj <- RunPCA(seurat_obj, features = features_to_use)

seurat_obj <- RunUMAP(seurat_obj, dims = 1:10)
seurat_obj <- FindNeighbors(seurat_obj, dims = 1:10)
seurat_obj <- FindClusters(seurat_obj, resolution = 0.5)
#####impose a threshold on marker (i.e CD8) expression#####

seurat_objRNA@data["CD8A", ] > threshold_value |
seurat_obj@assays$RNA@data["CD8B", ] > threshold_value, "CD8+", "CD8-")

FeaturePlot(seurat_obj, features = c("CD8A", "CD8B"))


dist_matrix <- Dist(seurat_obj@assays$RNA@data, method = "euclidean", features = c("CD8A", "CD8B"))

seurat_obj <- FindNeighbors(seurat_obj, custom.distances = dist_matrix)
seurat_obj <- FindClusters(seurat_obj, resolution = 0.5)















#####Add features that are a binary version of features#####

gene_list <- c("Runx3", "Eomes", "Zeb2", "Id2", "Tbx21", "Prdm1", "Tox", "Znf683", "Tcf7", "Foxo1")
new_gene_list <- paste0(gene_list, "B")

for (i in 1:length(gene_list)) {
gene <- gene_list[i]
new_gene <- new_gene_list[i]

objnew_gene <- ifelse(GetAssayData(obj, slot = "counts")[gene, ] > 0, 1, 0)
}

head(obj@meta.data)




cd8_data <- FetchData(iodide.data.sc, vars = c("Cd8a", "Cd8b1"))

cd8_filtered <- cd8_data[(cd8_dataCd8b1 > 0), ]

cd8_filteredCd8a + cd8_filtered$Cd8b1

ggplot(cd8_filtered, aes(x = rownames(cd8_filtered), y = CD8_total)) +
geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "skyblue") +
labs(title = "CD8 Expression Across Cells with Measured CD8 Counts",
x = "Cells", y = "Total CD8 Expression (CD8A + CD8B)") +
theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) +
theme_minimal()


gene_of_interest <- c("Cd8a")#,"Cd8b1")

gene_data <- FetchData(iodide.data.sc, vars = gene_of_interest)

num_cells_with_expression <- sum(gene_datagene_of_interest > 0)
num_cells_with_expression2 <- sum(gene_datagene_of_interest > 3)
num_cells_with_expression2 <- sum(rowSums(gene_data >= 2) > 0)

cat("Number of cells with at least 2 count of", gene_of_interest, ":", num_cells_with_expression2, "\n")


genes_of_interest <- c("CD8A", "CD8B") # You can add more genes to this list

gene_data <- FetchData(obj, vars = genes_of_interest)


num_cells_with_expression <- sum(rowSums(gene_data > 0) > 0)

cat("Number of cells with at least one count for any of the genes (", paste(genes_of_interest, collapse=", "), "):", num_cells_with_expression, "\n")

item.title: Action items
item.description:
cellity and sinqc
can remove low quality cells automatically, but require fastq read files to do so.
Removing Doublets
DoubletFinder is straightforward to implement. Requires a fully processed seurat object, including cell identities assigned to clusters.
Removing Ambient RNA

item.title: BestPractices
item.description:
BestPracticesTutorialPublication
notes follow -
raw data - CellRanger, indrops, zUMIs do this.
Assigning reads to cell barcodes --- "Demultiplexing"
gene alignment, quantifiation
yields read/count matrix of BARCODES vs genes.
BC some barcodes may be tagged on more than one cell (doublet)
or no cells (empty droplet, empty well)
QC Metrics - (coviariates)

Counts per barcode
Genes per barcode
%mt genes per barcode
classification of low quality cells from scrnaseq
Other QC Metrics

Read Quality - Filter on reads with over 30 in Q30 scores
Datasets with low Q30 scores in barcode read have poor cell assignment
poor Q30 scores in the RNA read will not be able to be aligned
Typical values 60-70% throughout, with highest in the barcode read
Alignment QC - 40% or higher exonic reads is good
Direct calculation ? - the % of reads that are in the dataset after count matrix is made. Can estimate the cell input (hemacytometer counts, flow counts) If we get around the same number of cells in a count matrix, amazing.
QC metrics must be considered together, not in isolation. EG high mt counts may suggest involvement in respiration. Cells/barcodes with low counts may be quiescent cells, high counts may be physically large cells.
Then how to make thresholding decisions?
Be permissive.
Consider whether a threshold removes more than the expected # of cells
Datasets with mixed cell populations may have multiple peaks in QC metrics

Addressing QC parameters in an analysis workflow changes the output of downstream analysis methods ie pathways, clustering etc.
Knowing whether the QC filters/methods applied are adequate is impossible to know, but can be inferred by performance of downstream analysis methods.
Therefore, recursive analysis is required.
Determine QC metrics independently across samples as in this example

the simple approach is de-select cells that have unusually high gene counts. In practice what does that mean i'm not sure.
DoubletDecon is one doublet detection method
Scrublet
DoubletFinder

soupx
also (https://academic.oup.com/gigascience/article/9/12/giaa151/6049831)
removes ambient rna by analyzing empty droplets?????

The wetlab process has a lot of room for error. Cell digestion, isolation, sorting, capture/bead, RT, sequencing.
Count depth can vary greatly simply due to these processes, even when processed the same. Therefore identical cells could potentially look very different.
Normalization is required to address this

a simple way is to scale the gene expression per cell by the total library size
CPM normalization. or scaling by the median count depth per cell
the assumption here is that all cells initially had equal RNA and the only difference in RELATIVE amounts is due to sampling error.
Downsampling has the same assumption. It randomly samples reads/counts so that all cells have a certain # of counts or less. (deletes data)
These approaches aren't great for mixed populations. Maybe they are good for very uniform populations
this pooling method (scran) does a linear regression of genes after pooling all the cells, to estimate a size factor. and available here?
Scran outperforms other normalization methods one example in batch correction and DE analysis
Normalization with bulk methods was used at first but zero-inflated sc Data required new approaches
one example and a second one https://doi.org/10.1038/nmeth.4292

Can account for more complex unwanted variation.
examples from Satijas? group

All these normalizations above apply to cells... Normalization could be applied to genes.
The central question is - should all genes be weighted equally?

put the way the paper i'm following today - "is the magnitude of gene expression informative for the importance of the gene"
can evaluate normalization tools with scone


3 important effects
Distance between log-txformed expression values become logFC, which is what we are typically trained to evaluate
log-txformation mitigates the mean-variance relationship in single cell data by reducing technical noise?
reduces the skewness of the data, so that assumptions of normality can be (sorta) met for downstream tools
SCRNASEQ is not lognormal data powsimrPaperDiscusses?
Log transformation can introduce error

scmap
https://doi.org/10.1038/nmeth.4644

item.title: NormalDataScript
item.description:
Seurat Dependencies
SeuratPackages <- c('Seurat', 'dplyr','patchwork','glmGamPoi','presto','BPCells','sctransform', 'hdf5r','Azimuth','ggplot2','Signac','SeuratWrappers','BSgenome.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38') lapply(SeuratPackages, library, character.only=TRUE) Copy

Data is processed by cellRanger and imported via the Read10x function
pbmc <- CreateSeuratObject(counts = pbmc.data, project = "control", min.cells = 3, min.features = 200) pbmc <- CreateSeuratObject(counts = pbmc.data, project = "control", min.cells = 3, min.features = 200) pbmc[["percent.mt"]] <- PercentageFeatureSet(pbmc, pattern = "^mt-") VlnPlot(pbmc, features = c("nFeature_RNA", "nCount_RNA", "percent.mt"), ncol = 3) Copy




plot1 <- FeatureScatter(pbmc, feature1 = "nCount_RNA", feature2 = "percent.mt") plot2 <- FeatureScatter(pbmc, feature1 = "nCount_RNA", feature2 = "nFeature_RNA") plot1 + plot2 Copy






Examining VlnPlot - ~5% mt cutoff seems appropriate
Looking at featureplots - about 4200 features seems appropriate. could just do an even 4000.
subsetting:
pbmcSubset <- subset(pbmc, subset = nFeature_RNA > 200 & nFeature_RNA < 4000 & percent.mt < 5) Copy


Normalizing, showing top variable genes:
pbmcSubset <- NormalizeData(pbmcSubset, normalization.method = "LogNormalize", scale.factor = 10000) pbmcSubset <- FindVariableFeatures(pbmcSubset, selection.method = "vst", nfeatures = 2000) top40 <- head(VariableFeatures(pbmcSubset), 40) plot1 <- VariableFeaturePlot(pbmcSubset) plot2 <- LabelPoints(plot = plot1, points = top40, repel = TRUE) plot2 Copy



all.genes <- rownames(pbmcSubset) pbmcSubset <- ScaleData(pbmcSubset, features = all.genes) #alternatively, use this to regress out unwanted factors: pbmcSubset <- ScaleData(pbmcSubset, vars.to.regress = "percent.mt") pbmcSubset <- RunPCA(pbmcSubset, features = VariableFeatures(object = pbmcSubset)) print(pbmcSubset[["pca"]], dims = 1:5, nfeatures = 5) Copy
PC_ 1 Positive: Gimap3, Sept1, Rpl12, Gimap4, Ms4a4b Negative: Ifitm3, Lyz2, Alox5ap, Lst1, Ifitm2 PC_ 2 Positive: Cd79a, Ebf1, Cd79b, Cd74, Igkc Negative: Nkg7, AW112010, Ms4a4b, Id2, Ccl5 PC_ 3 Positive: Cd300e, Pglyrp1, Adgre4, Fabp4, Ear2 Negative: Tmem176b, C1qc, C1qb, C1qa, Cxcl16 PC_ 4 Positive: Cd3d, Cd3e, Il7r, Cd3g, Tcf7 Negative: Klrb1c, Ncr1, Gzma, Klre1, Prf1 PC_ 5 Positive: Tmsb10, Fn1, Vim, Crip1, Ccr2 Negative: C1qa, C1qc, C1qb, Slco2b1, Cd63 Copy
saveRDS(pbmcSubset, file = "") Copy
Second seurat object with regressed out mt genes
pbmcSubsetRegressedMt <- ScaleData(pbmcSubset, vars.to.regress = "percent.mt") pbmcSubsetRegressedMt <- RunPCA(pbmcSubsetRegressedMt, features = VariableFeatures(object = pbmcSubsetRegressedMt)) Copy
DimPlot(pbmcSubset, reduction = "pca") DimPlot(pbmcSubsetRegressedMt, reduction = "pca") Copy

PCA on just subsetted data, not regressed for mt

PCA on regressed data:


These are used to determine the number of principal components with which to do dimensional reduction
both analyses (regressed out Mt or no regression) look essentially identical:
this is the regressed dataset

From this it looks like all of the variability is captured up to PC18, although 15 might be a lower cutoff. proceeding with 18

#these perform dimensional reduction with the PC we selected. #Dimensions are the PC pbmcSubset <- FindNeighbors(pbmcSubset, dims = 1:18) pbmcSubset <- FindClusters(pbmcSubset, resolution = 0.5) pbmcSubsetRegressedMt <- FindNeighbors(pbmcSubsetRegressedMt, dims = 1:18) pbmcSubsetRegressedMt <- FindClusters(pbmcSubsetRegressedMt, resolution = 0.5) pbmcSubset <- RunUMAP(pbmcSubset, dims = 1:18) DimPlot(pbmcSubset, reduction = "umap") Copy
Cluster output for subsetted data no regressed MT:

pbmcSubsetRegressedMt <- RunUMAP(pbmcSubsetRegressedMt, dims = 1:18) DimPlot(pbmcSubsetRegressedMt, reduction = "umap") Copy
Cluster output for data with regressed mt:


#examples of how to find markers in a cluster # find all markers of cluster 2 cluster2.markers <- FindMarkers(pbmc, ident.1 = 2) head(cluster2.markers, n = 5) # find all markers distinguishing cluster 5 from clusters 0 and 3 cluster0.markers <- FindMarkers(pbmcSubset, ident.1 = 5, ident.2 = c(0, 3)) head(cluster5.markers, n = 5) # find markers for every cluster compared to all remaining #cells, report only the positive ones pbmc.markers <- FindAllMarkers(pbmc, only.pos = TRUE) pbmc.markers %>% group_by(cluster) %>% dplyr::filter(avg_log2FC > 1) Copy
cluster0.markers <- FindMarkers(pbmc, ident.1 = 0, logfc.threshold = 0.25, test.use = "roc", only.pos = TRUE) Copy
#visualize canonical markers across the umap plot FeaturePlot(pbmc, features = c("MS4A1", "GNLY", "CD3E", "CD14", "FCER1A", "FCGR3A", "LYZ", "PPBP", "CD8A")) Copy
working with regressed image:

cluster#
0
1 Cd79a, Ms4a1 Iglc3 Iglc2... - B cells
2 Cd8a, Cd8b1, Cd3e, Cd3g, - CD8 T cells
3
4 Cd79a - another B cell cluster
5: Eomes, Klrg1 - NK cells
6: Cd4, Cd3e, Cd3g - CD4 T cells
7: Cd8a, Cd8b1 - CD8 T cells
8
9
10
11
12

#starting with the 10x data imported from cellranger scPBMC[["percent.mt"]] <- PercentageFeatureSet(pbmc, pattern = "^mt-") scPBMC <- SCTransform(pbmc, vars.to.regress = "percent.mt", verbose = FALSE) Copy
pbmc <- RunPCA(pbmc, verbose = FALSE) pbmc <- RunUMAP(pbmc, dims = 1:30, verbose = FALSE) pbmc <- FindNeighbors(pbmc, dims = 1:30, verbose = FALSE) pbmc <- FindClusters(pbmc, verbose = FALSE) DimPlot(pbmc, label = TRUE) Copy
asdf

Phenotyping experiment - Goal to show a reproducible phenotype in the LCNV Model

Primary readout - Flat mount to measure lesion size
4 mice in 1 laser group - Eyes taken at D7
4 mice in 2 laser group - Eyes taken at D14
Young mice (to be purchased soon) with the rationale of that is routine for the field. Discussion as to the relevance to AMD (being a disease of older people)
Time Course Experiment - Goal is to determine what timepoint has the most immune cell population in the eye after inducing a memory/recall response with laser burn.

Readout - CD8 mem Flow Panel. Quantify the number of CD8 memory cells in the eye after injury.
Time points relative to the laser burn: Day 1, 4, 7
2 Groups - 1 laser burn events (1L) and 2 laser burn events (2L)

E1_TimeCourseLaserLCNV Flow on D7 1LB mice
Regun is doing FA and FP, train with him if possible
Experiment2_E2_PhenotypingLCNV Staining - Regun?

item.title: DevNotesP1
item.description:
CD8 mem Flow Panel
This panel (P1) was run on RPE and Regun observed DP CD4/CD8 cells. Quite a lot.
Assumption is that these cells are an artifact, but we need to make sure they are not occurring in the spleen. If no DP cells are present in the spleen then the panel should be valid for the RPE also.
Same case with DN
CD3 clone x? had issues


first run on 2024-09-16 - did not observer any double positive cells.
CD3 on spleen titrated 1ul < 2ul < 3ul

Collect eyes and spleen from 3 mice (6 eyes) treated with sodium iodide on 2024-09-11
Stain and Digest spleen+RPE for flow CD8 mem Flow Panel
Talk with Regun about LCNV model/Planning for generating mice
spleen with full CD8 mem Flow Panel
RPE with full CD8 mem Flow Panel
titrate antibodies vs spleen needs plan
titrate antibodies vs rpe needs plan, needs info on how many cells
also use additional CD3 antibodies in single colors
Be at DMEI @ 10:30 Aurora flow.

item.title: PilotStudy1
item.description:
#Coculture #CD8BeadIsolation #TCellCulture #CytotoxicityAssay #InVitro
We did a pilot study of our CD8-EyeCupExpt
2 Mice Sodium Iodide treated. Eyes and spleen collected day 3.
Regun dissected eyecup, CES isolated CD8 T cells
We had four experimental conditions:
Healthy eye + healthy cd8 (HH)
healthy eye + injured cd8 (HI)
injured eye + healthy cd8 (IH)
injured eye + injured cd8 (II)
Metric: Fluorescence microscopy - Stained for Live/Dead (link later), and phalloidin to observe cells.
Results:

RPE death evident in HH
RPE death in HI
Unclear if CD8 cell death is due to RPE cytotoxicity or unclear.
Overall conclusions:
Worth repeating
Next step and changes:

get fixable live/dead dye
determine cd8 culture conditions
#Coculture #CD8BeadIsolation #TCellCulture #CytotoxicityAssay #InVitro

item.title: LearnObsidian
item.description:
markdown cheat sheet
tasks: - [ ] "taskname"

Flat mounted and stained 4 eye cups from 1 sodium iodide mouse 1 healthy mouse from PilotStudy1

Discussed Vitreal Injection Assay. Began planning for Vitreal_Injections
With Anti-CD8
Adoptive Transfer of CD8 into eye

Ran CD8 mem Flow Panel with Dr. Chen.
Notes - CD3 had poor separation
Dr. Chen provided two other CD3 AB aliquots to try.
Will run panel for formal training on 2024-09-16
3 mice treated with sodium iodide, harvest on Monday 2024-09-16

#CD8 #CytotoxicityAssay #TCellCulture #CD8BeadIsolation

Kids Counselor at 12pm. Must walk out the door by 11:15.
Must get protocol for TissueDigestion***REGUN PROTOCOL*** for flow w/Dr. Chen on 2024-09-16
[ ]start CD8CultureConditions
This got delayed, this will be performed at a later date TBD (note 9.12.2024)

We are developing an assay to test CD8 cytotoxicity in eye cup

Isolate CD8T from healthy spleen for RegunEtAlPaperStructure
Conditions
DMEM
DMEM + 10%FBS
DMEM + 10%FBS + IL-2 (concentration?)
RPMI + 10%FBS + IL-2
Timepoints
24, 48, 72 hours.
Total Wells = 4 conditions x 3 timepoints = 12 wells.
500,000 cells/well = 6e6 cells.
Approx. 3 mice given ProcedureMetrics
Metric: Viability on 2024-09-12, 2024-09-13, 2024-09-14, 2024-09-15
#CD8 #CytotoxicityAssay #TCellCulture #CD8BeadIsolation

CD8CultureConditions
Viability Day 1:fin.csv could not be found.

CD8CultureConditions
Viability day 2

CD8CultureConditions
Viability day 3:
Prepare for Monday-

Put flow panel in separate box
Label tubes
Media for digestion
Set out enzyme aliquots for digestion
DMEM-10%FBS and DMEM-F12
Did barrier facility orientation.

item.title: GIT instructions for a simple mind
item.description:
find the folder that i ran git init on.....XD
for the obsidian its in /Export folder
using obsidian plugin, export my files to the export folder (select all)

if access is a problem, generate SSH key in terminal
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com" Copy
ssh-keygen -t rsa -C "any comment can be here" -t = The type of the key to generate -C = comment to identify the key Copy
two keys are made, the private key and public key.
public key is in a .pub folder
that goes in github
have to add the new key to the ssh-agent
$ eval "$(ssh-agent -s)" > Agent pid 59566 Copy
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_(whatever_numbers_here)
ssh-add -L
lists public key parameters of all identities currently represented by the ssh agent
ssh-add -l -E md5 Copy
this will check if ssh lost my key. if it lists a checksum it has the key
setting the github url... either this
git remote set-url origin https://github.com/username/repository.git
or
git remote set-url origin sandelc@github.com:sandelc/obsidian.io.git
unsure the difference
was easier to use a personal access token from github and use https
git remote set-url origin https://@github.com/sandelc/obsidian.io.git
tried to git pull
then to a push after updating the folder and i got this
git push origin master
To https://github.com/sandelc/obsidian.io.git
! [rejected] master -> master (non-fast-forward)
error: failed to push some refs to 'https://github.com/sandelc/obsidian.io.git'
hint: Updates were rejected because the tip of your current branch is behind
hint: its remote counterpart. If you want to integrate the remote changes,
so i did this
git config.pull.rebase false
which i understand will make a 'merge'
then git pull origin master
then git push origin master worked
https://sandelc.github.io/obsidian.io/ still live 9.15.2024
item.guid: Git/GIT instructions for a simple mind.md

item.title: TissueDigestion***REGUN PROTOCOL***
item.description:
Regun's protocol:

Minimum 6 eyes required
Mice must be perfused
Prepare DMEM-F12 on ice (serum free)
Prepare DMEM + 10% FBS
Enucleate eyes, keep in 1x PBS
Dissect eye removing anterior portion
Retains RPE+Choroid
Cut tissue into small pieces
Add digestion cocktail 50ul collagenase, 50ul dispase, 50ul trypsin (0.25%).
Max volume 1ml
MAX 20min @ 37
Inactivate with DMEM 10%FBS
the 20 min time is relatively calibrated to 1ml
Filter 45um, grind with syringe rubber stopper
Spin @ 300xg 5min 5accel 3brake
resuspend DMEM 10%FBS
Proceed to staining or etc
Estimated time for digestion ~1hour
Regun's experience - good viability by flow. like 90% good. Immediately go into flow stain.
Fix/perm - losing lots of cells. troubleshoot

item.title: Imputation in single cell
item.description:
Considered imputation on scRNAseq datasets
Imputation may not be useful for downstream analysis
Another 2023 benchmarking study showed imputation improved simulated datasets, but barely improved real datasets

this study did recommend SAVER and NE for downstream analysis.
DrImpute and scImpute for "discovering novel subtle cell types"
ARLA may be a useful imputation tool bc it preserves zeros
